content: Added DFS as the other tag, altho nicer, is a duplicate.
Unless I'm mistaken, Loops and Branches and its validator are incorrect. I count 17 a's and 15 b's, all connected.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: On the whole, I approve. You might consider developing a more complex sequel.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Looking good. Easy enough to code, still a good challenge
Simple and fun :+1:

I like the statement, but I would prefer to remove the reference to settlers of catan in the first sentence. Cause settlers of catan uses a hex board, and players knowing the boardgame might be confused by the square board. 

I think the reference in the bottom "Inspired ..." is enough to give credit.
For added challenge, add a circular road.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Straightforward and relevant to a game I've always wanted to learn how to play.
Very good. I don't know what else to say really lol. I already told you what I liked about it.
It wouldn't be any extra work, and good validation, to also output the length of the road.
That's a good idea, I'll add it. Thanks!

Oops, I may have approved too soon. Test cases the user sees and validators they don't should be different to avoid allowing solutions to pass that are hard-coded and don't actually solve the problem.

I like this idea and have been working on it for a little while. My original code was unable to find the correct solutions for those additional cases, but I'll keep working on it. Also, adding loops and branches require some sort of recursion or other advanced technique and make the problem much more complicated than I originally intended (albeit more fun and interesting).
Good point, updated
There are 17 total, but not 17 consecutive. You would have to double count multiple roads in order to include all 17 in the total.

I've just removed the tag "Depth first search". See also:

https://forum.codingame.com/t/learning-tags-cleanup-normalization/186567
I included "non-repeating" in the description to help make it more clear.
I'll have to change my approach then, and see how easy it is, or not.
Updated, they're slightly different now
Cool. For consistency you could also consider "# 0" for the default case.
